entry.title: MBA Survey: "Share of Mortgage Loans in Forbearance Slightly Decreases to 3.48%"
entry.summary: Note: This is as of July 18th. From the MBA: Share of Mortgage Loans in Forbearance Slightly Decreases to 3.48% The Mortgage Bankers Associationâ€™s (MBA) latest Forbearance and Call Volume Survey revealed that the total number of loans now in forbearance decreased by 2 basis points from 3.50% of servicersâ€™ portfolio volume in the prior week to 3.48% as of July 18, 2021. According to MBAâ€™s estimate, 1.74 million homeowners are in forbearance plans. The share of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac loans in forbearance decreased 2 basis points to 1.81%. Ginnie Mae loans in forbearance decreased 1 basis point to 4.35%, while the forbearance share for portfolio loans and private-label securities (PLS) increased 5 basis points to 7.38%. The percentage of loans in forbearance for independent mortgage bank (IMB) servicers remained the same relative to the prior week at 3.68%, and the percentage of loans in forbearance for depository servicers decreased 1 basis point to 3.61%. â€œAs is typical for mid-month reporting, forbearance exits slowed, and there was a slight increase in new requests. The net result was a small drop in the share of loans in forbearance â€“ the 21 st consecutive week of declines,â€ said Mike Fratantoni, MBAâ€™s Senior Vice President and Chief Economist. â€œThe forbearance share decreased for GSE and Ginnie Mae loans, but increased for portfolio and PLS loans, as new forbearance requests increased for this category.â€ emphasis added Click on graph for larger image. This graph shows the percent of portfolio in forbearance by investor type over time.Â Most of the increase was in late March and early April 2020, and has trended down since then. The MBA notes: "Total weekly forbearance requests as a percent of servicing portfolio volume (#) increased relative to the prior week: from 0.03% to 0.04%"

entry.title: Housing Inventory July 26th Update: Inventory Increased 3% Week-over-week, Up 31% from Low in early April
entry.summary:
Tracking existing home inventory will be very important this year. Click on graph for larger image in graph gallery. This inventory graph is courtesy of Altos Research.
As of July 23rd, inventory was at 403 thousand (7 day average), compared to 640 thousand the same week a year ago.Â That is a decline of 37.1%.
A week ago, inventory was at 391 thousand, and was down 39.6% YoY.Â Â
Seasonally, inventory has bottomed.Â Â Inventory was about 31.4% above the record low in early April.
Mike Simonsen discusses this data regularly on Youtube.Â Â
Altos Research has also seen a significant pickup in price decreases - almost back to the level of a year ago - although still well below a normal rate for July.

entry.title: Black market for appointments
entry.summary: Tech savvy scalpers are causing problems for online booking. But switching from first-come-first-served rules to a so-called batch system may stop them, according to a paper in the American Economic Review.

entry.title: How policy shapes culture
entry.summary: To what extent does policy shape culture? We spoke with Natalie Bau about her paper in the American Economic Review on the effect that pension reform had on traditional family arrangements in Ghana and Indonesia.

entry.title: Do Environmental Markets Improve on Open Access? Evidence from California Groundwater Rights
entry.summary: Journal of Political Economy, Ahead of Print.

entry.title: To catch a polluter
entry.summary: High pollution emitters sometimes game the system by putting out more emissions on days when regulators' air quality monitors aren't operating, according to a paper in the American Economic Review.

entry.title: School vs neighborhood effects
entry.summary: Moving to a better neighborhood can have a lasting impact on childrenâ€™s educational attainment. Better school systems are likely the biggest reason why, according to a paper in the American Economic Journal: Economic Policy.

entry.title: Build and Debug C++ with WSL 2 Distributions and Visual Studio 2022
entry.summary: This post is written by Erika Sweet, a Program Manager on Microsoftâ€™s C++ Team. The post Build and Debug C++ with WSL 2 Distributions and Visual Studio 2022 appeared first on Windows Command Line.

entry.title: Windows Terminal Preview 1.10 Release
entry.summary: Itâ€™s Windows Terminal release day! This release introduces Windows Terminal Preview to version 1.10 and Windows Terminal will be updated to version 1.9 soon. Windows Terminal will include all of the features listed in the 1.9 blog post except for the default terminal setting and the ability to edit actions using the settings UI. The post Windows Terminal Preview 1.10 Release appeared first on Windows Command Line.

entry.title: Understanding the child penalty
entry.summary: Biological factors, such as childbearing and breastfeeding, canâ€™t explain earnings inequality between men and women after the birth of a child, according to a paper in the American Economic Review: Insights.

entry.title: Family ties
entry.summary: Ties between royal European families, particularly through marriage, secured peace between dynasties and played a big role in the decline in war after 1800, according to a paper in the American Economic Journal: Applied Economics.

entry.title: Systematic Bias in the Progress of Research
entry.summary: Journal of Political Economy, Ahead of Print.

entry.title: More than a few bad apples
entry.summary: Police officers have a lot of discretion when writing speeding tickets, according to a paper in the American Economic Review. We spoke with author Steven Mellow about how that leads to higher discrimination against minorities and what might fix it.

entry.title: Feasible Joint Posterior Beliefs
entry.summary: Journal of Political Economy, Ahead of Print.

entry.title: The fallout of bankruptcy reform
entry.summary: Proponents of bankruptcy reform legislation in the early 2000s argued that lenders would pass along their higher debt recovery to consumers in the form of lower interest rates. A paper in the American Economic Journal: Macroeconomics found that rates did in fact decline.

entry.title: Earnings Dynamics, Changing Job Skills, and STEM careers
entry.summary: The US labor market is particularly dynamic for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) jobs, with new technologies proliferating throughout workplaces every year. This technological change is the engine of long-run productivity growth and rising living standards. In the shorter run, however, workers in technology-intensive occupations must constantly learn on the job, or risk becoming [â€¦] The post Earnings Dynamics, Changing Job Skills, and STEM careers appeared first on Microeconomic Insights.
